en.csharp_lesson3_title: C# III - Async and Advanced LINQ
en.csharp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content: Console.WriteLine is a function that displays text on the screen. It's the most basic way to output information in C#.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex1_slide2_content: Write Console.WriteLine("text"); with the message in quotes inside the parentheses.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex2_comment1: Put "CSharp" in a box called name
en.csharp_lesson1_ex2_comment2: Display the contents of the box
en.csharp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content: A variable is like a box that stores data. You can put values in it and take them out later.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'string name = "value";' to create a text variable. Use 'int' for numbers.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment1: Put 10 in a box called x
en.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment2: Put 5 in a box called y
en.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment3: Display the sum of x and y
en.csharp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content: C# can do math! Use + for addition, - for subtraction, * for multiplication, and / for division.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex3_slide2_content: Write 'x + y' to add variables. You can use the result directly in Console.WriteLine.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex4_comment1: Output the remainder of 10 divided by 3
en.csharp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content: The % operator gives you the remainder after division. 10 % 3 equals 1 because 10 divided by 3 leaves remainder 1.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'a % b' to get the remainder. Useful for checking if numbers are even or odd!
en.csharp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content: += adds to a variable, -= subtracts from it. 'hp += 20' is the same as 'hp = hp + 20'.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content: Use 'variable += value;' to add, 'variable -= value;' to subtract. There's also *= and /=!
en.csharp_lesson1_ex6_comment1: Put 10 in a box called age
en.csharp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: String interpolation lets you insert variables directly into text using $ and curly braces {}.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex6_slide2_content: Write $"I am {age} years old" to insert the age variable into the string.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content: An array stores multiple values of the same type. Each element has an index starting from 0.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex7_slide2_content: Create with 'string[] colors = {"Red", "Blue"};'. Access with 'colors[0]' for the first element.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content: An if statement runs code only when a condition is true. It's how programs make decisions.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex8_slide2_content: Write 'if (condition) { code }'. Use > for greater than, < for less than, == for equals.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex9_comment2: Branch based on whether 20 or older
en.csharp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content: If-else lets you handle both cases: what to do when true, and what to do when false.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex9_slide2_content: Write 'if (condition) { } else { }'. The else block runs when the condition is false.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content: && means AND (both must be true), || means OR (at least one must be true), ! means NOT.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex10_slide2_content: Write 'if (a > 80 && b > 10)' to check if both conditions are true.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content: Foreach automatically goes through each item in a collection, one by one.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex11_slide2_content: Write 'foreach (var item in collection) { }'. The loop variable gets each element.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content: A Dictionary stores key-value pairs. You can quickly find a value using its key.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex12_slide2_content: Create with 'new Dictionary<string, int>()'. Add with 'dict["key"] = value;'.
en.csharp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content: A method is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. It helps organize your program.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content: Inheritance lets a class use properties and methods from another class. The child class inherits from the parent.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex1_slide2_content: Use 'class Child : Parent' to inherit. The child gets all public and protected members.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content: Override lets a child class provide its own version of a parent's method.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex2_slide2_content: Mark parent method 'virtual', child method 'override'. Both must have same signature.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: An interface defines a contract - what methods a class must have. It's like a promise.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content: Define with 'interface IName { }'. Implement with 'class MyClass : IName'.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: Properties provide controlled access to class data. They look like fields but have get/set logic.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'public int Age { get; set; }' for auto-property, or define custom get/set blocks.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content: List<T> is a resizable collection. Unlike arrays, you can add and remove items easily.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex5_slide2_content: Create with 'new List<int>()'. Use Add(), Remove(), Count, and indexer [].
en.csharp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Where filters a collection, returning only items that match a condition.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex6_slide2_content: Use 'list.Where(x => x > 5)' to get items greater than 5. Returns IEnumerable.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content: Select transforms each item in a collection into something new.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'list.Select(x => x * 2)' to double each value. Returns transformed collection.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content: A lambda is a short anonymous function. It's great for LINQ and event handlers.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex8_slide2_content: Write 'x => x * 2' for single expression, or '(x, y) => { return x + y; }' for block.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content: Try-catch handles errors gracefully. Code in try runs, catch handles any exceptions.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex9_slide2_content: Use 'try { } catch (Exception e) { }'. Add 'finally { }' for cleanup code.
en.csharp_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content: The ?. operator safely accesses members. If the object is null, it returns null instead of throwing.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content: Async/await lets code wait for slow operations without blocking. Great for I/O and network.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content: Mark method 'async Task'. Use 'await' before async calls. Returns Task or Task<T>.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: OrderBy sorts a collection. Use OrderByDescending for reverse order.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'list.OrderBy(x => x.Name)' to sort. Chain with ThenBy for secondary sort.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content: First throws if empty, FirstOrDefault returns null/default. Choose based on your needs.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content: Use 'list.First(x => x > 5)' or 'list.FirstOrDefault(x => x > 5)' for safe access.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content: Any returns true if at least one matches. All returns true only if every item matches.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'list.Any(x => x > 10)' or 'list.All(x => x > 0)'. Returns bool.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content: Sum adds all values. Average calculates the mean. Both work on numeric collections.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content: Switch expressions are concise pattern matching. They return a value based on the input.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content: Dictionary provides fast key-value lookup. Use TryGetValue for safe access.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'dict.TryGetValue(key, out var value)' to safely get values without exceptions.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content: You can include expressions and formatting in interpolated strings.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content: Use '$"{value:F2}"' for 2 decimal places, '$"{date:yyyy-MM-dd}"' for date format.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: Records are immutable reference types. They have built-in equality and nice ToString.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content: Define with 'record Person(string Name, int Age);'. Copy with 'person with { Age = 30 }'.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content: Using ensures resources are properly disposed when you're done with them.
en.csharp_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content: Use 'using var file = new StreamReader(path);'. Disposes automatically at scope end.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content: Generics let you write code that works with any type. The type is specified when used.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex1_slide2_content: Define with 'class Box<T> { T value; }'. Use with 'new Box<int>()'.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content: Constraints limit what types can be used with generics. Ensures the type has needed members.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'where T : IComparable' or 'where T : class, new()' to add constraints.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content: A delegate is a type-safe function pointer. It holds a reference to a method.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content: Define with 'delegate int Calculate(int x);'. Assign with 'Calculate calc = MyMethod;'.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content: Func is a built-in delegate that returns a value. Last type parameter is the return type.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'Func<int, int, int> add = (a, b) => a + b;'. Types: inputs first, return last.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content: Action is a built-in delegate for methods that don't return a value (void).
en.csharp_lesson4_ex5_slide2_content: Use 'Action<string> log = msg => Console.WriteLine(msg);'. All type params are inputs.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content: GroupBy organizes items into groups based on a key. Each group has a key and items.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content: Use 'list.GroupBy(x => x.Category)'. Access with 'group.Key' and iterate group items.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content: Chain ?. for deep null checking. Use ?[] for safe array/indexer access.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'obj?.Child?.Name' or 'array?[0]'. Returns null if any part is null.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content: The ?? operator returns the left value if not null, otherwise the right value.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex8_slide2_content: Use 'name ?? "Unknown"' for default. Use '??=' to assign only if null.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content: Records support inheritance, custom methods, and non-destructive mutation with 'with'.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content: Use 'var updated = original with { Name = "New" };'. Creates a copy with changes.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content: Init properties can only be set during object initialization. They're immutable after creation.
en.csharp_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content: Use 'public string Name { get; init; }'. Set with object initializer syntax only.
en.go_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content: fmt.Println is a function that displays text on the screen. It's the most basic way to output information in Go.
en.go_lesson1_ex1_slide2_content: Write fmt.Println("text") with the message in quotes inside the parentheses.
en.go_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content: A variable is like a box that stores data. Use := for short variable declaration in Go.
en.go_lesson1_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'x := 10' for short declaration or 'var x int = 10' for explicit type.
en.go_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content: Go can do math! Use + for addition, - for subtraction, * for multiplication, and / for division.
en.go_lesson1_ex3_slide2_content: Write 'x + y' to add variables. You can use the result directly in fmt.Println.
en.go_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content: The % operator gives you the remainder after division. 10 % 3 equals 1 because 10 divided by 3 leaves remainder 1.
en.go_lesson1_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'a % b' to get the remainder. Useful for checking if numbers are even or odd!
en.go_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content: += adds to a variable, -= subtracts from it. 'hp += 20' is the same as 'hp = hp + 20'.
en.go_lesson1_ex5_slide2_content: Use 'variable += value' to add, 'variable -= value' to subtract. There's also *= and /=!
en.go_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: fmt.Printf lets you format strings with placeholders like %d for numbers and %s for strings.
en.go_lesson1_ex6_slide2_content: Write fmt.Printf("I am %d years old", age) to insert the age variable into the string.
en.go_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content: A slice is a flexible, dynamic view of an array. It can grow and shrink unlike fixed-size arrays.
en.go_lesson1_ex7_slide2_content: Create with 'colors := []string{"Red", "Blue"}'. Access with 'colors[0]' for the first element.
en.go_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content: An if statement runs code only when a condition is true. Note: Go doesn't need parentheses around conditions.
en.go_lesson1_ex8_slide2_content: Write 'if condition { code }'. Use > for greater than, < for less than, == for equals.
en.go_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content: If-else lets you handle both cases: what to do when true, and what to do when false.
en.go_lesson1_ex9_slide2_content: Write 'if condition { } else { }'. The else block runs when the condition is false.
en.go_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content: && means AND (both must be true), || means OR (at least one must be true), ! means NOT.
en.go_lesson1_ex10_slide2_content: Write 'if a > 80 && b > 10' to check if both conditions are true.
en.go_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content: Range iterates over slices, maps, and other collections. It returns both index and value.
en.go_lesson1_ex11_slide2_content: Write 'for i, v := range slice { }'. Use _ to ignore index: 'for _, v := range slice'.
en.go_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content: A map stores key-value pairs. You can quickly find a value using its key.
en.go_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content: A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task. It helps organize your program.
en.go_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content: Go functions can return multiple values at once. This is commonly used for returning results with errors.
en.go_lesson2_ex1_slide2_content: Define with 'func divide(a, b int) (int, int) { return a/b, a%b }'. Receive with 'q, r := divide(10, 3)'.
en.go_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content: Go uses explicit error handling. Functions return an error value that should be checked.
en.go_lesson2_ex2_slide2_content: Return 'errors.New("message")' for errors, 'nil' for success. Check with 'if err != nil'.
en.go_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: A pointer holds the memory address of a variable. Use & to get address, * to access value.
en.go_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content: Use 'p := &x' to get pointer. Use '*p = 20' to change the value through the pointer.
en.go_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: A struct groups related data together. It's Go's way of creating custom types.
en.go_lesson2_ex4_slide2_content: Define with 'type Person struct { Name string; Age int }'. Create with 'p := Person{Name: "Go", Age: 10}'.
en.go_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content: A method is a function with a receiver. It lets you attach behavior to types.
en.go_lesson2_ex5_slide2_content: Define with 'func (r Rectangle) Area() int { return r.Width * r.Height }'. Call with 'rect.Area()'.
en.go_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: An interface defines a set of methods. Any type implementing those methods satisfies the interface.
en.go_lesson2_ex6_slide2_content: Define with 'type Speaker interface { Speak() string }'. Types implicitly implement interfaces.
en.go_lesson2_ex7_comment1: Execute at function end with defer
en.go_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content: Defer schedules a function call to run when the surrounding function returns. Great for cleanup!
en.go_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'defer file.Close()'. Multiple defers run in LIFO order (last in, first out).
en.go_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content: A goroutine is a lightweight thread managed by Go runtime. It enables concurrent execution.
en.go_lesson2_ex8_slide2_content: Use 'go functionName()' to start a goroutine. The function runs concurrently.
en.go_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content: Channels allow goroutines to communicate safely. They can send and receive values.
en.go_lesson2_ex9_slide2_content: Create with 'ch := make(chan int)'. Send with 'ch <- value'. Receive with 'value := <-ch'.
en.go_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content: An anonymous function has no name. It can capture variables from its surrounding scope (closure).
en.go_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content: Define with 'func(x int) int { return x * 2 }'. Assign to variable or call immediately.
en.go_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content: Generics let you write functions and types that work with any type. Added in Go 1.18.
en.go_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content: Use 'func Print[T any](v T)' to accept any type. 'any' is an alias for 'interface{}'.
en.go_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: The 'comparable' constraint allows only types that support == and != operators.
en.go_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'func Contains[T comparable](slice []T, item T) bool' to compare elements.
en.go_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content: Make creates slices, maps, and channels with specified size. It allocates and initializes memory.
en.go_lesson3_ex3_slide2_content: Use 'slice := make([]int, 5)' for length 5, or 'make([]int, 0, 10)' for length 0, capacity 10.
en.go_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content: Append adds elements to a slice. Use ... to expand a slice when appending another slice.
en.go_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'slice = append(slice, 4, 5)' or 'slice = append(slice1, slice2...)' to combine.
en.go_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content: Copy copies elements from source to destination slice. It returns the number of elements copied.
en.go_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content: Use 'n := copy(dst, src)'. The destination must be pre-allocated with make.
en.go_lesson3_ex6_comment1: Wait for multiple channels with select
en.go_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content: Select waits on multiple channel operations. It executes whichever case is ready first.
en.go_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content: Use 'select { case v := <-ch1: ... case v := <-ch2: ... }'. Add 'default:' for non-blocking.
en.go_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content: Range can iterate over maps, returning key-value pairs. Order is not guaranteed.
en.go_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'for key, value := range myMap { }'. Use _ to ignore either key or value.
en.go_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content: Type creates a new distinct type based on an existing type. It enables type safety and methods.
en.go_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content: Use 'type Celsius float64'. Now Celsius is a distinct type from float64.
en.go_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: Embedding includes one struct inside another, promoting its fields and methods. It's composition.
en.go_lesson3_ex9_slide2_content: Use 'type Child struct { Base }' without field name. Access Base's fields directly on Child.
en.go_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content: Panic stops normal execution. Recover catches panics in deferred functions for graceful recovery.
en.go_lesson3_ex10_slide2_content: Use 'defer func() { if r := recover(); r != nil { ... } }()' before code that might panic.
en.go_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content: Mutex ensures only one goroutine can access a resource at a time. It prevents race conditions.
en.go_lesson4_ex1_slide2_content: Use 'var mu sync.Mutex', then 'mu.Lock()' and 'defer mu.Unlock()' around critical sections.
en.go_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content: WaitGroup waits for a collection of goroutines to finish. It's a counter-based synchronization.
en.go_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'wg.Add(1)' before goroutine, 'defer wg.Done()' inside, and 'wg.Wait()' to block until done.
en.go_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content: Context carries deadlines, cancellation signals, and values across API boundaries.
en.go_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content: Use 'ctx := context.Background()' as the root context. Pass context as the first parameter.
en.go_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content: WithCancel creates a context that can be cancelled. Child goroutines can check for cancellation.
en.go_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(parent)'. Call 'cancel()' to signal cancellation.
en.go_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content: Duration represents elapsed time. Use constants like Second, Millisecond for readable code.
en.go_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content: Marshal converts Go values to JSON bytes. Use struct tags to control JSON field names.
en.go_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content: Use 'data, err := json.Marshal(value)'. Add 'json:"name"' tags to struct fields.
en.go_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content: Unmarshal parses JSON bytes into Go values. Pass a pointer to the destination variable.
en.go_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content: Use 'err := json.Unmarshal(data, &result)'. The destination must be a pointer.
en.go_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content: Split divides a string into a slice using a separator. Part of the strings package.
en.go_lesson4_ex9_comment1: Convert string to int with Atoi
en.go_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content: Atoi converts a string to an integer. It returns the number and an error if conversion fails.
en.go_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content: Use 'num, err := strconv.Atoi("42")'. Always check the error before using the result.
en.go_lesson4_ex10_comment1: Get command line args with Args
en.go_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content: os.Args is a slice containing command line arguments. Args[0] is the program name.
en.go_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content: Use 'args := os.Args[1:]' to get arguments after the program name.
en.python_lesson1_course_description: Learn Python basics: print, variables, if statements
en.python_lesson3_course_description: Learn to define and use functions
en.python_lesson4_course_description: Learn to read and write files
en.javascript_lesson2_course_description: Learn to interact with web pages
en.csharp_lesson3_course_title: C# III - Async and Advanced LINQ
en.go_lesson4_course_description: Learn sync, context, and JSON handling
en.cpp_lesson1_ex1_slide2_content:

C++`std::cout`
`cout` Character OUTput

`<<` 

****
 `<<` ""


****
```cpp
#include <iostream>  // 
int main() {
    std::cout << "C++" << std::endl;
    return 0;
}
```

****
- `std::endl`: 
- `#include <iostream>`:
en.cpp_lesson1_ex2_slide2_content:
# 

1, 2, 3 `int`
`int` Integer

****
```cpp
int age = 20;  // age20
std::cout << age << std::endl;  // age
```
=> 20 

**C**
C `printf("%d", age)` C++ `std::cout << age`
en.cpp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_title: When You Want to Increase Values
en.cpp_lesson2_ex1_slide2_content:
# class 

`class`
`public:`

****
```cpp
class Dog {       // Dog
public:           // 
    std::string name;  // 
};

// 
Dog d;            // d
d.name = "Pochi"; // 
```

****
- `public`: 
- `.`:
en.cpp_lesson2_ex4_slide2_content:
# & 

 `&` 

****
```cpp
int x = 10;
int& ref = x;  // ref  x 
ref = 20;      // x  20 
```
en.cpp_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
# template<typename T>

`template<typename T>``T` 

****
```cpp
// T 
template<typename T>
T add(T a, T b) {
    return a + b;
}

// 
add(1, 2);       // T = int 
add(1.5, 2.5);   // T = double 
```

****
- `T` 
- 
-
en.cpp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
# 

**auto**

****
`auto` 

****
```cpp
auto x = 42;        // 42  int
auto pi = 3.14;     // 3.14  double
auto name = "Alice"; //   const char*
```

****
en.cpp_lesson3_ex2_slide1_title: What is a Range-based for Loop?
en.cpp_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
# 

**nullptr**

****
`nullptr` 

****
```cpp
int* p = nullptr;  // p
if (p == nullptr) {
    cout << "null" << endl;  // null
}
```

C++11 `NULL`  `nullptr`
en.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
# 

**constexpr**

****
210ml10ml

****
```cpp
constexpr int square(int x) {
    return x * x;
}
constexpr int val = square(5); // 25
```
en.cpp_lesson3_ex4_slide2_content:
#  vs 

`const`  `constexpr` 

****
```cpp
// const: OK
const int a = getValue();     // 

// constexpr: 
constexpr int b = 10 * 10;    // 100
```

****
- `const`: 
- `constexpr`: 

****
`constexpr`
en.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
# 

**shared_ptr**

****
11

****
```cpp
auto p1 = make_shared<int>(42);  // 1
auto p2 = p1;                     // 2
// p1 p2 
// p2 
```

****
`unique_ptr` 1`shared_ptr`
en.cpp_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
# make_shared 

`shared_ptr` `make_shared` 

****


****
```cpp
// 
auto p = make_shared<int>(100);  // 100

// 
shared_ptr<int> p(new int(100));
```

** make_shared **
- 1
- 
- 

`make_shared<>()`
en.cpp_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
# 

**std::move**

****


****

en.c_lesson1_ex7_slide2_content:
# Use { } to Create Arrays

When creating an array, you list the data inside `{ }` curly braces.
To access the contents of an array, you specify the position using `[ ]` square brackets.

**Super Important Point!**
In programming, **the first data is at position 0**, not 1!
We start counting from 0, not 1.

**Let's look at actual code:**
```c
int scores[] = {100, 50};  // An array with two pieces of data: 100 and 50
printf("%d\n", scores[0]); // Position 0 = 100 will be displayed
printf("%d\n", scores[1]); // Position 1 = 50 will be displayed
```

**How to remember:**
1st data  position 0
2nd data  position 1
(Position = Order - 1)

cs.csharp_lesson3_title: C# III - Async and Advanced LINQ
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content: Console.WriteLine is a function that displays text on the screen.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex1_slide2_content: Write Console.WriteLine("text"); with the message in quotes.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex2_comment1: Put "CSharp" in a box called name
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex2_comment2: Display the contents of the box
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content: A variable is like a box that stores data.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex2_slide2_content: Use 'string name = "value";' to create a text variable.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment1: Put 10 in a box called x
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment2: Put 5 in a box called y
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex3_comment3: Display the sum of x and y
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content: C# can do math! Use + - * / for operations.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex4_comment1: Output the remainder of 10 divided by 3
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content: The % operator gives you the remainder after division.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex4_slide2_content: Use 'a % b' to get the remainder.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex5_slide1_content: += adds to a variable, -= subtracts from it.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex6_comment1: Put 10 in a box called age
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content: String interpolation lets you insert variables into text using $ and {}.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex6_slide2_content: Write $"I am {age} years old" to insert variables.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content: An array stores multiple values of the same type.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content: An if statement runs code only when a condition is true.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex9_comment2: Branch based on whether 20 or older
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content: If-else handles both true and false cases.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content: && means AND, || means OR, ! means NOT.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content: Foreach goes through each item in a collection.
cs.csharp_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content: A method is a reusable block of code.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content: Inheritance lets a class use properties from another class.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content: Override lets a child class provide its own method version.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content: An interface defines a contract for classes.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content: Properties provide controlled access to class data.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content: Where filters a collection by condition.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content: Select transforms each item in a collection.
cs.csharp_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content: A lambda is a short anonymous function.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content: Async/await lets code wait without blocking.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content: First throws if empty, FirstOrDefault returns null.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content: Any returns true if at least one matches.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content: Sum adds all values, Average calculates mean.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content: Switch expressions are concise pattern matching.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content: Include expressions and formatting in strings.
cs.csharp_lesson3_ex10_slide1_content: Using ensures resources are properly disposed.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content: Generics let you write code for any type.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content: Constraints limit what types can be used.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content: A delegate is a type-safe function pointer.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content: Func is a delegate that returns a value.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content: Action is a delegate for void methods.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content: ?? returns left value if not null, otherwise right.
cs.csharp_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content: Init properties can only be set during initialization.
